President Trump’s vow to build a wall on the US-Mexico border is a racist appeal to the most extreme and radical elements in our society and goes against the very essence of what this country stands for. I wholeheartedly condemn this move and this administration’s misguided effort to round up undocumented immigrants, while cutting federal grants to sanctuary cities like those in L.A. County.   We are a nation of immigrants composed of hardworking families, students, and people who wake up every morning and go to work to make an honest dollar. Trump is deliberately targeting the most vulnerable members of our society, including children and families fleeing violence, who we should be protecting.   Sanctuary cities are implemented to encourage immigrants without legal status to cooperate with police and reduce crime. Trump’s executive order will upend this established trust and effectively turn police officers into ICE agents, resulting in more instances of unreported crime due to the fear of police interaction. This, in turn, encourages criminals to take advantage of this fear, and transforms undocumented immigrants into easy targets.

Over the weekend, my office received the sad news that Doug Lunn had passed away. Doug, a session musician in L.A. who had played with Frank Zappa and many others, was self-employed for most of his life and had rarely been able to have health insurance until the Affordable Care Act.   Just in time, too.  Doug lost the ability to play guitar and discovered it was because he had uncontrolled diabetes. He was able to get care and get back to work.  Then in 2014, he was diagnosed with 2 different types of cancer.    Doug said that thanks to his health coverage, he went from dying of cancer, to living with it. My thoughts are with his daughter, Donnie, and wife, Vida, who got five more years with Doug because of the ACA, and who graciously allowed me to share Doug’s story. Today, Los Angeles lost a star and I, a dear friend.   The light Robert Guillaume brought into a room was as impenetrable as the light that shined down on him on stage. He was a fighter; someone who carried himself by his own weight from the inner city of St. Louis to the bright lights of Hollywood. A trailblazer for black actors and actresses throughout the country, Robert’s contributions to beating back racial prejudice on stages across the country cannot be overstated. In 1985, he became the first black actor to win an Emmy for lead actor in a comedy series for his role in Benson, a feat that has unfortunately remained nearly insurmountable. Just this year, Donald Glover became only the second black actor to win the award.    Always dedicated and inspired by his craft, Robert continued to challenge his limits, a truly inspirational journey to witness. I’ll forever remember his performance as the first black actor to sing the title role of "Phantom of the Opera," appearing with an all-white cast, leaving jaws dropped and audiences remarking “We had no idea Benson could sing, let alone sing opera!”   But sing he did, and sing he shall. His endearing essence and comforting spirit will be so missed. We could all afford to live by his words:  "To assuage bitterness requires more than human effort. Relief comes from a source we cannot see but can only feel. I am content to call that source love."  Robert, may you rest now, without pain or worry, wrapped in the love you hold dear.
